results.title: Alfonzo: a long way from home
results.creator_credit: Gustavo Nieto Roa and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Alfonzo is a weaver in the Ecuadorian community of Otavalo. The Otavalo weavers are threatened by the competition of mass produced garments made on industrial looms. The film follows Alfonzo to Quito, where he seeks to sell his work and that of his fellows. Finally a man comes to town who claims to know how to put Otavalo’s cottage industry back into competition. Narrated by Ben Park.

results.title: Tame the wind
results.creator_credit: Selig Alkon, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Shows how we are now moving to learn to modify the weather to our own ends. The film offers some examples of how weather modification is practised today, and also takes viewers to the Nile Basin where a meteorological survey evokes a far-off dream of making some of the world’s driest desert terrain fertile and fruitful.

results.title: Our time in the garden
results.creator_credit: Ron Blau, Susan Woll and Central Studios
results.brief_description: Fifty-year old films from the home movies of the Blau family, Berlin Jews who lived in the Grunewald until 1933. Striking impressions of a happy life before the coming of Fascism. Made by Ron Blau. Voice of Gerda Blau.

results.title: Interviewing the Abused Child.
results.brief_description: Through a series of actual and recreated interviews, children of various ages, subjected to different types of abuse, are seen and heard as professionals talk with them. A perceptive training film which will benefit anyone with an occasion to interview a child abuse victim

results.title: Shutdown
results.creator_credit: Laura Sky, David Springbett, Don Hopkins and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Documents the closing-down of an American-owned branch plant with all the personal trauma that such a decision causes to the workers. The employees discuss the dilemma of working in an economy dominated by foreign ownership and the lack of government action to protect jobs in American-owned branch plants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laura Sky, David Springbett, Don Hopkins and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Different approach
results.creator_credit: Fern Field, Jim Belcher and Belfern Productions
results.brief_description: A young filmmaker, hired to make a sombre straight-forward film about the reasons employers should hire the disabled, decides instead to take an innovative, irreverent approach to what is usually a piously hush-hush subject. The film shows him screening his film to an incredulous audience and trying to convince them that his different approach is the right one. Stars Michael Keaton with cameo appearances by Martin Mull, Ed Asner, Jim Nabors and Carroll O’Connor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fern Field, Jim Belcher and Belfern Productions

results.title: Tasmania is...
results.creator_credit: Jane Bampton and Tasmanian State Film Unit
results.brief_description: The activities and scope of the Directorate of Industrial Development and Trade are highlighted. Covers the broad spectrum of industry and looks at the social attitudes held by the Tasmanians themselves.

results.title: Brave banners
results.brief_description: Traces the origin and use of flags and heraldry in such diverse situations as Nelson’s historic signal and the unfurling of the Stars and Stripes on the moon. Concludes with the history and development of the Australian flag.

results.title: Time out: time to kill
results.brief_description: Discusses the effects retirement has on some people and looks at the problems of retirement when leisure is a full time job. When they leave work at 65, many feel cheated and futile, yet this should be their biggest opportunity to enjoy leisure. Some reap the full benefits of their retirement but what is going wrong for the others?

results.title: Rivers at work
results.creator_credit: Lew Davidson, Film Producers Guild, Films of Scotland and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Modern development of her mountain waters to bring electrical power to Scotland began at Sloy. Like so many Scottish lochs, Sloy drew its water from only a small area of Highland country - not enough in itself for a massive power project. The collecting capacity of Sloy was consequently extended by means of tunnelling through the mountainsides to pipe the waters of neighbouring glens together. When this project was successfully completed, others were undertaken. Narrated by John Grierson. Photography, Arthur Lavis and John Wiles. Editing, John Tanner. Sound, Ron Abbott.
